ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments:
A deep understanding of the important topics in algorithmic game theory: matching markets; online learning; mechanism design; price of anarchy etc.
as well as some hard math/probability tools used to solve them
I learned about matching algorithms, fair division, FTRL, incentive compatibility, mechanism design, revenue maximization, and many other fascinating topics at the intersection of CS and ECON.
Game theory
Various notions of stability and equilibria in economic settings and their computational properties; fixed-point theorems; online learning and its connection to games; mechanism design.
I learned a lot of algorithms and game theory topics. I also learned how to write proofs more confidently and engage difficult problems with critical thinking.

-Game Theory-esque course:
Stable Matchings
Matching Markets
Voting Rules
Introduction to Game Theory
Min-max Theorem
Online Learning
Fair Division
Mechanism Design
Mechanism Design without Money
Price of Anarchy
Cryptocurrencies

A computational introduction to topics in game theory and incentive design. It was a rigorous proof class that covered material on incentive compatibilities, finding equilibrium, and designing mechanisms. There was a large focus on proofs of existance and efficiency, i.e. what is findable. The class covered a lot of interesting material, covering essential math basics and giving a good servey to the topic of computational economics, and how computers help find equilibria.
algorithmic game theory
Really interesting concepts within game theory.
Some interesting concepts and models
game theory, voting & mechanism design
Information on game theory and algorithmic approaches to game theory.
Game theory, equilibriums, mechanism design

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: the topic covered was very interesting
The only weakness of the class is that it was sometimes hard to get up for class at Kline at 9AM

This class has no weaknesses. It is absolutely spectacular. The professor presents the material clearly and succinctly, with a fundamental understanding of the material. He uses the blackboard unless it makes more sense to use slides (such as for pictures, or simply because the material is review so he can move faster through it on the slides). He provides spectacular lecture notes and is fantastically helpful during OHs. The material is wide-ranging, but I don't view this as a negative.
Good course
Interesting topics and good breadth.

The course is extremely well designed. The topics are all very interesting and vary in difficulty. There are four well-spaced problem sets of appropriate length. The lecture notes are extremely helpful as well. The only change I would recommend is that the exams include more questions. The exams were only two questions so if you didn't understand a certain topic or proof you basically failed that question.

Strengths: Well-organized, reasonable problem sets, many office hours, prof was very enthusiastic about helping


Weaknesses: if you're interested in this material, then it'll be a fabulous course for you. But it is very proofs-based and definitely amongst one of the most intellectually challenging courses I've taken

The course was excellent. Lectures were good. Notes were very helpful. Psets and exams were both fair and really focused on understanding the material at a high level, how to prove similar things, and how to apply it, instead of nitty gritty memorization from class. The course really was centered around exploring and getting an understanding of the material which I really appreciated. It was pretty interesting and very fun. The psets all felt appropriate. There was plenty of help avaliable.
Good lecture notes and exams. Homework was difficult but helped to prepare for the exam and relearn the material from the lecture.
The content of the course is really interesting and Professor Zampetakis is a great teacher and very supportive.
Lecture notes are extremely detailed and helpful which is amazing.
The course is well taught and problem sets are interesting, exams are quite simple.
Very well-organized course. Professor Zampetakis is great and accommodating, and the homework problems follow closely what was done in class.

The course demonstrated Professor Zampetakiss deep understanding and thoughtful structuring of the material. Each topic logically progressed into the next, providing a clear roadmap of the curriculum. The intellectual rigor of the course demanded significant time outside the classroom to fully grasp the concepts. However, Professor Zampetakis's exceptional lecture notes were invaluable, surpassing any online resources I encountered. They provided comprehensive explanations of the class content. Once the material was understood, I found the homework and exams to be exceptionally fair and reasonable. Additionally, the office hours were notably beneficial.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! Prof Zampetakis is an amazing professor. Take this class with him!
Absolutely, especially with this professor!
It will be helpful if you want to learn game theory.
I would recommend this course to satisfy the CSEC requirement or if your very comfortable with math and proof writing.
I hgihly rec as an alternative to ECON 351 for CS+Econ majors! Prof Zampetakis is a very clear lecturer, very responsive, very reasonable with exams and psets.

Yes! If you want another theory class, this is a great one. It is very mathy, but provides a strong foundation. It gives you a sense of some of the questions that are being asked by theorists, how to approach them, and a very strong sense of how computer science is applied. Professor Zampetakis is a gem, with wonderful explanations. The work and grading were also very fair. While the material was tough, it felt like I was just expected to wrestle with it and get comfortable, instead of memorizing things from class. This was really a course centered on student learning, and I loved it.
Yes, workload is not too bad.

The content itself is very challenging, but the workload is quite small which balances things out. The opportunity for a final project of the student's choice is also really great. You should only take if you have a specific interest in game theory and want to explore it from an algorithmic perspective.
It's an interesting course. Lecture notes are very detailed which is extremely helpful.

I would definitely recommend this course to any student looking to gain insight about how computer science and economics overlap. This course was recently made as an alternative that could satisfy the game theory requirement for the CS-Econ joint major, and I am very happy this alternative was made available because I found this course much more approachable than ECON 351 (which I also tried but dropped). While this course was by no means less intellectually challenging than ECON 351, I feel like the course was designed in a way that was much more approachable and friendly to computer science-focused students. It also helped that we didn't have a long, difficult problem set every week.
The course is pretty good. I would recommend taking both this course and ECON 351, as they offer very different perspectives on game theory.
Yes. It's a well-taught class, and you can learn a lot. The teaching staff is definitely a plus.

Yes! If you liked Algorithms and are interested in its economic applications this class is fantastic. Professor Zampetakis is also a gemone of the best professors Ive had at Yale. If youre a CS & Econ major, youre probably deciding between this class and Econ 351; take this class. Its phenomenally organized, interesting, and fair.
